sen.j: 神田 孝平（かんだ たかひら、文政13年9月15日 (旧暦)（1830年10月31日） - 明治31年（1898年）7月5日）は幕末の洋学者、明治時代の兵庫県県令、元老院議官、貴族院議員。
sen.e: Takahira Kanda (31 October 1830 - 5 July 1898) was a scholar in the end of Edo Period, the governor of Hyogo Prefecture, Councilor of the Senate and Councilor of House of Peers in the Meiji Period.
Takahira KANDA (31 October 1830 - 1898) was a scholar in the end of Edo Period, the governor of Hyogo Prefecture, Councilor of the Senate and Councilor of House of Peers in the Meiji Period.
sen.cmt: ・「5 July」を削除しました（7月5日は明治31年の月日で、あり1898年のものとは一致しません）。・Takahira Kanda→Takahira KANDA
sen.e: Takahira KANDA (31 October 1830 - 1898) was a scholar in the end of Edo Period, the governor of Hyogo Prefecture, Councilor of the Senate and Councilor of House of Peers in the Meiji Period.
Baron
He was a Baron.
He was a Baron.

sen.j: 美濃国不破郡岩手村（現・岐阜県不破郡垂井町岩手）出身。
sen.e: He was born in Iwate Village, Fuwa District, Mino Province (now known as Iwate, Tarui Village, Fuwa District, Gifu Prefecture).
He was born in Iwate Village, Fuwa District, Mino Province (now known as Iwate, Tarui Village, Fuwa District, Gifu Prefecture).
He was born in Iwate Village, Fuwa District, Mino Province (now known as Iwate, Tarui Village, Fuwa District, Gifu Prefecture).
He was usually addressed as Kohei.
He was usually addressed as Kohei.
He was usually addressed as Kohei.
Career
Career
Career

sen.j: 牧善輔・松崎慊堂らに漢学を、杉田成卿・伊東玄朴に蘭学を学ぶ。
sen.e: He learned the study of Chinese classics from Zensuke MAKI and Kodo MATSUZAKI, and Western studies from Seikei SUGITA and Genboku ITO.
He learned the study of the Chinese classics from Zensuke MAKI and Kodo MATSUZAKI, and the study of Western sciences from Seikei SUGITA and Genboku ITO.
sen.cmt: ・Chinese classics→the Chinese classics・Western studies→the study of Western sciences（「漢学」と「蘭学」が同じ形で表示されるようにしました。）
sen.e: He learned the study of the Chinese classics from Zensuke MAKI and Kodo MATSUZAKI, and the study of Western sciences from Seikei SUGITA and Genboku ITO.

sen.j: 1862年（文久2年）、幕府蕃書調所教授となる。
sen.e: In 1862, he came a teacher at Bakufu's Bansho Shirabesho.
In 1862, he became a Bakufu's Bansho Shirabesho teacher.
sen.cmt: ・came→became・a teacher at Bakufu's Bansho Shirabesho→a Bakufu's Bansho Shirabesho teacher
sen.e: In 1862, he became a Bakufu's Bansho Shirabesho teacher.

sen.j: 1868年（明治元年）に明治政府に1等訳官として招聘される。
sen.e: In 1868, he was called from the Meiji Government to work as their First Rank Interpreter.
sen.cmt: 定訳が見つからなかったので1等訳官をfirst rank interpreterと訳しました。
sen.e: In 1868, he was enlisted by the Meiji Government as the first ranked interpreter.
sen.cmt: ・was called from→was enlisted by・「to work」を削除しました。・as their First Rank Interpreter→as the first ranked interpreter
sen.e: In 1868, he was enlisted by the Meiji Government as the first ranked interpreter.

sen.j: 1871年（明治4年）11月20日 (旧暦)に兵庫県令（現在の兵庫県知事）に就任し、1876年（明治9年）9月3日まで務める。
sen.e: On November 20, 1871, he was appointed to become the governor of Hyogo Prefecture and worked until September 3, 1876.
On November 20, 1871, he become the governor of Hyogo Prefecture and worked until September 3, 1876.
On November 20, 1871, he become the governor of Hyogo Prefecture and worked until September 3, 1876.

sen.j: その間、1870年（明治3年）頃より地租改正を建議するとともに農民の土地売買の自由を唱えるなど当時としては画期的な提案を行い、1873年（明治6年）の地方官会議では議長を務めてその実現に貢献する。
sen.e: During this period, he set out a couple of proposals which were thought to be very unique and original at that time; one was the Land Tax Reforms and the other was the removal of restrictions on the sale and purchase of land among peasants, and in 1873 he contributed to implement his proposals as the chairman in the local administrative assemblies.

During that time, he made landmark proposals such as the Land Tax Reforms and liberalization of land sales for peasants from 1870, and he chaired the local administrative assembly and contributed to the achievement of his proposals in 1873.
sen.cmt: ・During this period→During that time・「set out a couple of proposals which were thought to be very unique and original at that time;」→『made landmark proposals such as』と、簡潔にしました。・「the other was」削除しました。・「one was the Land Tax Reforms and the other was the removal of restrictions on the sale and purchase of land among peasants,」→『the Land Tax Reforms and liberalization of land sales for peasants from 1870』と、簡潔にしました。 ・in 1873 he contributed to implement his proposals as the chairman in the local administrative assemblies.→he chaired the local administrative assembly and contributed to the achievement of his proposals in 1873.
sen.e: During that time, he made landmark proposals such as the Land Tax Reforms and liberalization of land sales for peasants from 1870, and he chaired the local administrative assembly and contributed to the achievement of his proposals in 1873.

sen.j: 1876年に元老院議官、1890年（明治22年）に貴族院議員に選出。
sen.e: He was elected as Councilor of the Senate in 1876 and as Councilor of House of Peers.
He was elected as Councilor of the Senate in 1876 and as Councilor of House of Peers.
He was elected as Councilor of the Senate in 1876 and as Councilor of House of Peers.

sen.j: 死に際して男爵に叙任される。
sen.e: He was ennobled with the title of Baron at the time of his death.
He was ennobled with the title of Baron at the time of his death.
He was ennobled with the title of Baron at the time of his death.

sen.j: 欧米文献の欧米にも積極的で民選論の理論家としても知られる。
sen.e: He was enthusiastic over literatures from Europe and America and also known to be the theoretician of modern democracy.
He was enthusiastic over literatures from Europe and America and also known to be the theoretician of modern democracy.
He was enthusiastic over literatures from Europe and America and also known to be the theoretician of modern democracy.

sen.j: 明六社の一員であり、東京学士会院の会員でもある。
sen.e: He was a member of Meirokusha (Meiji 6 Society) as well as the Tokyo Academy.
He was a member of Meirokusha (Meiji 6 Society) as well as the Tokyo Academy.
He was a member of Meirokusha (Meiji 6 Society) as well as the Tokyo Academy.

sen.j: 養子の神田乃武（ないぶ）は東京外国語学校 (旧制)の初代校長。
sen.e: His adopted son, Naibu KANDA was the first president of Tokyo School of Foreign Studies (previous name).
His adopted son, Naibu KANDA was the first president of Tokyo School of Foreign Studies (previous name).
His adopted son, Naibu KANDA was the first president of Tokyo School of Foreign Studies (previous name).
